Can anyone out there explain why this is failing on 5.3? https://github.com/backdrop/backdrop/pull/3380

Off-and-on-and-off-and-on didn't help. No problem on a (local) 5.6, but 5.3 keeps throwing 500 errors. WHY?

Issue #3047: Add setting to add phone number field to contact forms by BWPanda · Pull Request #3380 · backdrop/backdrop
Fixes backdrop/backdrop-issues#3047 Replaces #3374
BTW: it's not the tests alone, it really throws 500: http://3380.backdrop.backdrop.qa.backdropcms.org/contact
Could it be the empty($config->get('phone'))? I believe empty() complains if it gets non-variable results.
In either case actually, there are several $config->get('phone'); may be best store that once in a variable.
What does "non-variable result" mean? If config didn't find anything, it returns NULL, empty(NULL) is TRUE.
The most frustrating thing (for @BWPanda mostly) is, that it works fine on 7.0. And I also verified that it works on 5.6. (locally). We're both clueless, what breaks it in 5.3.
I think @docwilmot might be on to something. Worth testing by changing that. First output it to a variable and then check if it's empty
Worth a try
too late, already tested. the error is "Can't use method return value in write context", which is essentially the same as what I suggested.
Ha! Thanks a million, @docwilmot. This is something that changed in 5.5, hence not reproducible on 5.6.
Curious what the rationale is on still supporting 5.3?

@Phil Ward I believe it's something to do with lots of web hosts and/or operating systems still including PHP 5.x as their default, out-of-the-box version. Since Backdrop wants to support the majority of users (especially those on shared hosting), that means supporting these older PHP versions. That's my understanding at least.
If we follow the WP minimum version we'll probably cover most hosts. I bet most hosts will upgrade when WP forces them to.
Looks like PHP 5.6 is the minimum version for WordPress now

CentOS 7 (which will be supported until June 30th, 2024) still supports PHP 5.4, which has been the marker used in the past: https://wiki.centos.org/About/Product#fndef-a91b3c0c287c782f9af063daff9e64b566d648c7-2

@Phil Ward There's a (sort of) ongoing discussion re raising the min version, for instance: https://github.com/backdrop/backdrop-issues/issues/4712 and duplicate(s). But I suppose, the discussion has stalled a bit.

Backdrop does not run on PHP 5.3.3 (or PHP 5.3.2?) · Issue #4712 · backdrop/backdrop-issues
Description of the bug In the requirements section on bakdropcms.org we clearly state that you need to be running PHP 5.3.2 or higher to run Backdrop. I have a server running two Drupal 7 sites (an...

Thanks all. I'll be in that boat to agree to raise it for the reason that it's too much overhead for a small community to have to maintain.

I'll note that from my experience, a lot of hosting environments might still offer it, some even out of the box, but they have gotten a LOT better with offering a way to choose multiple versions of PHP (including the latest) which means for a wide variety of people, changing it is a piece of cake.

The biggest problem is what is run for the control panel. This affects drush, composer and other PHP CLI stuff and isn't possible to change without upgrading the control panel.

When Backdrop was forked 6 years ago, the ability to choose was just starting to roll out from control panels and hosting companies. Now it's pretty common place. HostGator for example was stuck on cPanel v56 about 5 years ago, but they had their own in-house version of choosing PHP (which wasn't introduced to cPanel until around v70 I think).

So one thought before raising this, points back to telemetry. Once that can be implemented it will give a better direction on which versions to support.
Can we/should we put in a long-term deprecation warning, if there's not one already?

I guess one reason to support PHP 5.3 is to make upgrades from D7 more easy. D7 still supports PHP 5.3 (even if not recommended), see https://www.drupal.org/docs/7/system-requirements/php-requirements.

I do like the idea of being able to support D7 for a while... I have found that D7 and many modules work great on PHP 7.2 & 7.3 (jury is out on 7.4 as I just recently started testing it) 7+ is still a bit bugged for some older modules, but there's usually patches to fix them.

Sites that have a lot of custom code might be more concerned with this but if a dev is moving from D7 to something else (like Backdrop) and it has a lot of custom code, the devs probably understand it's time to update the code anyway. Makes me think we need to add PHP telemetry to the D7 BUS module at some point.

Can we/should we put in a long-term deprecation warning, if there's not one already?

Would 2.0 be a good candidate for this?
I don't think we need to support 5.3 in order to provide a good upgrade path from d7. The philosophy of Backdrop is to support for the 80% of users. Most users probably have little to no custom code.
I agree. I think that we should be supporting 5.6, and anything lower than that (down to 5.3) should be "best efforts".

I don't think we need to support 5.3 in order to provide a good upgrade path from d7. (...) Most users probably have little to no custom code.

I wasn't referring to custom code but about D7 sites running on a server with PHP 5.3 trying to uprade on the same server.

@Olaf Grabienski you really think there's a high percentage of hosting platforms that are locked at 5.3? From my experience, 5.3 is being dropped as being an option on a lot of hosting platforms.

I think that we should be supporting 5.6, and anything lower than that (down to 5.3) should be "best efforts".

What about bumping it up to 7 as the minimum with anything 5 being best efforts? Keep in mind, by the time a decision is made and implemented, there will be less people on 5.

If the thought is to dump 5.3 fairly soon, then yeah a 5.6 minimum makes sense with a 7 minimum coming in say 1-2 years.

I know I'll get some funny faces on this one, but the way I look at it, there's only a handful of people who are actually maintaining the code base for a whole bunch of people who aren't. I get that the software needs to be compatible for the community, but the community also consists of that very small group that has to maintain it. In my mind, it helps the community more by reducing the overhead requirements than it does making it more compatible with outdated languages. If the backwards compatibility requirement is gone, more time can be spent moving things forward. If the team was bigger, it would make more sense to devote time to a larger requirement window. Just my opinion :wink:
I like the logic. I don't know if it's controlling, but it's certainly a valid point.

I hope that some of these opinions get registered in Github, where they will be easier to find when the time comes to make a decision.
https://github.com/backdrop/backdrop-issues/issues/4712

Backdrop does not run on PHP 5.3.3 (or PHP 5.3.2?) · Issue #4712 · backdrop/backdrop-issues
Description of the bug In the requirements section on bakdropcms.org we clearly state that you need to be running PHP 5.3.2 or higher to run Backdrop. I have a server running two Drupal 7 sites (an...

I know it's not a perfect 1:1 with Backdrop's user base but if we borrow CiviCRM's telemetry data to see a real world example of how many people might be in this PHP 5.3 situation. Of 11439 sites: 9808 (PHP7+); 1080 (php 5.6); 551 (other, presumably <5.6). That's roughly 5% on PHP < 5.6 or 14% on PHP < 7.x.
https://stats.civicrm.org/?tab=technology

@Phil Ward I guess no high percentage on 5.3. I see it more as a ‚political‘ question if Backdrop should have higher requirements than D7 when we promote the upgrade path from D7 to Backdrop. Personally, I‘m absolutely fine with a higher version required but we should have in mind it‘s also a statement.

@Laryn Good stuff

@Olaf Grabienski I guess I'm not seeing the political gain :grinning_face_with_smiling_eyes:. It made since 4-6 years ago, but seeing how well D7 works on the latest versions of PHP, it's not much of a selling point any more.

I have mixed feelings about this and will say that if it's really a burden for us to maintain some of the earlier versions of PHP 5.x, we should CONSIDER our support level and make adjustments.

I guess I'm not seeing the political gain

The Political gain is that Backdrop CMS has promoted itself (in my opinion) as taking care of the users that were left behind by Drupal 8. If we start promoting policies and/or requirements that are MORE restrictive than those supported by Drupal 7, we MIGHT be sending a counter message (that does not mean that we should never do it).

The users still stuck on servers with PHP 5.3 are probably not going to Drupal 8. There is some risk that we loose any opportunity to bring them over to Backdrop if we make life harder for them than Drupal is.

Having said that, it's an argument that must be balanced against other arguments - including the ongoing costs to our community (as mentioned by @Phil Ward ).

I suspect that we may need to change our support version before 2.0 (Remember Backdrop 2.0 will not come before Jan 2025). But, we may want to keep ourselves in line with Drupal 7 until Drupal 7 is no longer supported (Nov 2022).

I'm undecided on this issue, listening to what others have to say.

Also, while Drupal core does support earlier versions of PHP, some contrib modules don't. Which means that effectively it getting harder and harder to maintain old Drupal 7 sites on servers with very old versions of PHP.

StPaulTim said:

...(Remember 2.0 will not come before Jan 2015).

No, it definitely will not. It will come significantly after.

I feel like the case for supporting old versions of PHP were valid 4-6 years ago but I'm not seeing the justification today.

Anything before PHP 7.2 is EoL which means Backdrop is promoting the potential use of versions that could be security problems with the language that runs Backdrop. I'm not saying we shouldn't support older versions, but a lot of time (in the computer world) has passed even since 5.6.

Does Drupals automated tests check full modules for PHP compatibility or is it just patches and commits? If there's a place to see which contribs are compatible with a given version of PHP, it might make things easier.

StPaulTim said:

...(Remember 2.0 will not come before Jan 2015).

Was this supposed to be 2025?

Was this supposed to be 2025?

Yes.
Thanks, yeah that's a long way off to have to change requirements...

No, it definitely will not. It will come significantly after.

It took @Phil Ward making my error explicit for me to appreciate the subtlety of this response. :-)

I've corrected the original typo (in case anyone comes late and is confused).
The current policy is that Backdrop CMS 2.0 will not be released before Jan 2025 (and certainly NOT before 2015).
Wow, I just realised that that'll mean Backdrop will be 10 years old before we have our first new major version... :surprise:
@BWPanda was the "wow" meant to be because you've realized how old Backdrop will be, or how old WE will be :sweat_smile:

@laryn a better metric would be how many CiviCRM sites there are that are on the current release (5.33?) and are running PHP 5.3. I'm guessing the number is zero since there's no way to run it on 5.3.
